# Procter & Gamble (PG) - Comprehensive Analysis Report

## 1. Company Overview

The Procter & Gamble Company (P&G) is a multinational consumer goods company focused on providing trusted, branded products of superior quality, performance and value to improve the lives of consumers around the world. Founded in Cincinnati in 1837 by William Procter, an English candlemaker, and James Gamble, an Irish soapmaker, P&G sells products in about 180 countries and territories throughout the world. The company was incorporated in Ohio in 1905, having first been established as a New Jersey corporation in 1890.

P&G operates through five business divisions: Beauty (18% of 2024 revenues) including Head & Shoulders, Herbal Essences, Pantene, Rejoice, Olay, Old Spice, Safeguard, Secret, SK-II, and Native; Grooming (8% of revenues) featuring Braun, Gillette, and Venus; Health Care (14% of revenues) with Crest, Oral-B, Metamucil, Neurobion, Pepto-Bismol, and Vicks; Fabric & Home Care (36% of revenues) including Ariel, Downy, Gain, Tide, Cascade, Dawn, Fairy, Febreze, Mr. Clean, and Swiffer; and Baby, Feminine & Family Care (24% of revenues) with Luvs, Pampers, Always, Tampax, Bounty, Charmin, and Puffs. The company owns brands that are in many cases the global brand leaders in their category, with many having market share greater than 25%. P&G generates 48% of its sales in the United States and 52% internationally.

## 2. Current Market Data

As of January 12, 2026, Procter & Gamble stock is trading at $143.46, with a market capitalization of approximately $332.04 billion. The stock trades at a price-to-earnings (P/E) ratio of 20.71 and offers a dividend yield of 2.9%. Over the past 12 months, the stock has traded between a 52-week low of $137.62 and a high of $179.99. The stock has declined 13.48% over the last year. This makes Procter & Gamble the world's 38th most valuable company according to market capitalization data.

## 3. Existing Products/Services

P&G's extensive product portfolio spans multiple categories:

• **Beauty**: Hair care (Pantene, Head & Shoulders, Herbal Essences), skin care (Olay, SK-II), personal cleansing (Old Spice, Secret, Native)
• **Grooming**: Razors and blades (Gillette, Venus), electric shavers (Braun)
• **Health Care**: Oral care (Crest, Oral-B), digestive health (Metamucil), respiratory care (Vicks), pain relief (Pepto-Bismol)
• **Fabric & Home Care**: Laundry detergents (Tide, Ariel, Gain), fabric softeners (Downy), household cleaners (Mr. Clean, Dawn), air fresheners (Febreze), cleaning tools (Swiffer)
• **Baby, Feminine & Family Care**: Diapers (Pampers, Luvs), feminine care (Always, Tampax), paper towels and tissues (Bounty, Charmin, Puffs)

## 4. Planned Products/Services/Projects

P&G has launched several new products recently, including Aussie Ultra Wonder curl-care collection (November 2025), Pantene Abundant & Strong Collection featuring a three-step system to reduce shedding and boost hair density, with clinical claims of reducing hair loss by up to 85% and visible thicker hair after one use. The company has also introduced Pampers size Pxxs, described as the world's smallest diaper for premature babies weighing less than 500g.

P&G partnered with Netflix's Stranger Things season 5 to relaunch its retro Letters to Tide campaign, introducing a boosted Tide Original Liquid formula claiming 25% more grease and stain-fighting power. The enhanced formula launched after approximately one year of development.

## 5. Growth Strategy

P&G remains committed to its integrated strategy focusing on a focused product portfolio of daily use categories where performance drives brand choice, superiority across product performance, packaging, brand communication, retail execution and consumer and customer value, productivity, constructive disruption and an agile and accountable organization, all aimed at delivering sustainable, balanced growth and value creation.

To maintain its position as a leading consumer goods company, P&G has outlined a comprehensive growth strategy encompassing product innovation, market expansion, digital transformation, and sustainability. The company is investing heavily in research and development to create superior products, developing new product categories, enhancing existing products, and incorporating sustainable practices into product formulations and packaging.

P&G is expanding its reach into emerging markets, where there is a growing middle class with increasing disposable income.

## 6. Current and Potential Major Clients

P&G sells its products through mass merchandisers, social and e-commerce channels, grocery and specialty beauty stores, membership club stores, drug and department stores, distributors, wholesalers, airport duty-free and high-frequency stores, pharmacies, electronics stores, and professional channels, as well as directly to consumers.

Key retail partners include major mass merchandisers like Walmart and Target, as well as various grocery chains, drug stores, and e-commerce platforms across global markets.

## 7. Financial Data & Performance

For Q4 2025, P&G reported net sales +2%, organic sales +2%, diluted EPS +17%, and core EPS +6%. For the full fiscal year 2025, net sales were flat at 0%, organic sales +2%, diluted EPS +8%, and core EPS +4%.

In 2024 the company made revenue of $84.34 billion, an increase over the previous year's $83.93 billion. For fiscal year 2024, organic sales grew 4%, core earnings per share grew 12%, and on a currency-neutral basis, core earnings per share were up 16%. Adjusted free cash flow productivity was 105%.

P&G returned over $14 billion to shareowners through $9 billion in dividends and $5 billion in share repurchases. The company announced a 7% dividend increase in April, marking the 68th consecutive annual dividend increase and the 134th consecutive year paying a dividend.

## 8. Market Shares

In the U.S. market, Procter & Gamble holds a significant share, competing primarily with Unilever, Johnson & Johnson, Colgate-Palmolive, and Kimberly-Clark. Many of P&G's brands have market share greater than 25% in their respective categories. As of fiscal 2024, 30 of P&G's top 50 category/country combinations were holding or growing market share.

## 9. Comparison to Competitors

Unilever is P&G's largest competitor by revenue, with approximately $60 billion in annual revenues compared to P&G's $76 billion. This competitive landscape pushes both firms to continuously innovate and improve their offerings to maintain their leading positions.

P&G competes primarily with Unilever, Colgate-Palmolive, and Kimberly-Clark in household and personal care products, while also facing competition from L'Oréal in beauty and Johnson & Johnson in consumer health segments.

P&G's competitive advantages include its strong brand portfolio with household names like Tide, Pampers, and Gillette, extensive market research capabilities enabling quick responses to consumer trends, robust supply chain and distribution network, and commitment to innovation reflected in continuous product development and sustainable practices.

## 10. Partnerships, Mergers and Acquisitions

P&G does not see the need for major mergers and acquisitions, preferring bolt-on acquisitions in daily-use categories. The $57 billion acquisition of Gillette in 2005 represents P&G's largest purchase, bringing Gillette razors, Duracell batteries, Braun appliances, and Oral-B products, creating the world's largest consumer goods company at the time.

Recent partnerships include:
• Partnership between Downy Rinse and USA Hockey with a sweepstakes for Winter Olympics tickets (2026)
• Pantene partnership with influencer Alix Earle to promote the Abundant & Strong 3-step system

## 11. Recent Developments

**Leadership Transition**: Shailesh Jejurikar, currently Chief Operating Officer, succeeded Jon Moeller as President and Chief Executive Officer effective January 1, 2026. Jon Moeller became Executive Chairman. Jejurikar has served as COO since 2021 and previously held the role of chief executive of global fabric and home care. From 2016 to 2021, he was the executive sponsor of global sustainability at P&G.

**Restructuring Plan**: In June 2025, P&G announced a portfolio and productivity plan to focus its portfolio and organization to improve its cost structure and competitiveness, expecting to incur non-core restructuring costs of approximately $1 to $1.6 billion before-tax over a two-year period, including cutting up to 7,000 non-manufacturing roles.

**Argentina Operations**: P&G completed a limited market portfolio restructuring with the substantial liquidation of its operations in Argentina in Q1 2025, recording incremental restructuring charges of $0.8 billion after tax.

**Sustainability Initiatives**: P&G's sustainability initiatives are embedded across operations, supply chains and brands, supported by four science-based pillars: climate, waste, water and nature. The company has achieved a 60% reduction in Scope 1 and 2 GHG emissions since 2010, sources over 99% renewable electricity and has maintained zero manufacturing waste to landfill since 2020. P&G has set a net zero target to achieve zero greenhouse gas emissions across its operations and supply chain by 2040, with an interim target to reduce emissions by 50% relative to 2010 emissions by 2030.

## 12. AI Investment Rating & Fair Value Assessment

**Investment Rating: 6.5/10**

**Rationale:**
- **Strengths**: Strong brand portfolio with global market leadership, consistent dividend growth (68 consecutive years of increases), stable cash flow generation, and successful ESG integration
- **Concerns**: Recent stock performance (-13.48% over 12 months), leadership transition uncertainty, significant restructuring costs ($1-1.6 billion), and challenging market conditions with expected tariff impacts
- **Moderate Growth Potential**: Low single-digit organic sales growth expected, mature markets limiting expansion opportunities

**Fair Value Estimate: $155-165**

Current trading at $143.46 suggests the stock may be undervalued relative to its defensive characteristics and brand strength. However, execution risks under new leadership and near-term headwinds from tariffs and restructuring costs warrant a cautious approach. The stock's defensive nature and strong dividend yield make it suitable for income-focused portfolios, but growth investors may find limited upside in the current environment.

**Recommendation**: HOLD with selective buying on further weakness below $140. The company's strong fundamentals and market-leading positions provide long-term value, but near-term catalysts are limited.
tldr_summary:
Procter & Gamble (P&G) is a multinational consumer goods company that produces and sells a wide range of trusted household and personal care brands across beauty, grooming, healthcare, home care, and family care categories in over 180 countries.

Key investment highlights include a robust portfolio of market-leading brands like Tide, Pampers, and Gillette, with many brands holding over 25% market share. The company is focusing on product innovation, emerging market expansion, and sustainability, with a recent leadership transition and ongoing restructuring to improve competitiveness. P&G generates consistent cash flow, has a 68-year history of dividend increases, and has committed to significant sustainability goals, including net-zero emissions by 2040. Major competitors include Unilever and Colgate-Palmolive, with P&G maintaining a strong competitive position through brand strength and continuous innovation.

The AI investment rating is HOLD at 6.5/10, with a fair value estimate of $155-165, reflecting the company's defensive characteristics balanced against near-term growth limitations and restructuring challenges.
